title: 1953–54 in English football
text:
The 1953–54 season was the 74th season of competitive <a href="football%20%28soccer%29">football</a> in <a href="England">England</a>.
Overview.
To celebrate the 90th anniversary of the <a href="Football%20Association">Football Association</a>, on 21 October 1953, England played a Rest of the World side picked by a <a href="FIFA">FIFA</a> Select Committee. After being 3-1 down following goals by <a href="L%C3%A1szl%C3%B3%20Kubala">László Kubala</a> and <a href="Giampiero%20Boniperti">Giampiero Boniperti</a>, <a href="Alf%20Ramsey">Alf Ramsey</a> scored a last minute penalty to draw the game 4-4. On 25 November 1953, the "<a href="Marvellous%20Magyars">Marvellous Magyars</a>" <a href="Hungary%20national%20football%20team">Hungary national football team</a>, led by prolific forward <a href="Ferenc%20Pusk%C3%A1s">Ferenc Puskás</a>, shocked football by <a href="England%20v%20Hungary%20%281953%29">defeating England 6–3 at Wembley Stadium</a>. On 25 May 1954, England lost to Hungary again, in Budapest, suffering their heaviest defeat, 7-1.
On the domestic scene, <a href="Wolverhampton%20Wanderers%20F.C.">Wolverhampton Wanderers</a>, managed by former player <a href="Stan%20Cullis">Stan Cullis</a>, won the league title for the first time, while their <a href="Black%20Country%20derby">local rivals</a> <a href="West%20Bromwich%20Albion%20F.C.">West Bromwich Albion</a> lifted the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> for the fourth time. Albion had also finished second in the league behind Wolves, while defending champions <a href="Arsenal%20F.C.">Arsenal</a> slipped to 12th this season. <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a>, the first postwar champions of the English league, were relegated to the Second Division in bottom place. <a href="Everton%20F.C.">Everton</a> were promoted to the First Division after three seasons in the Second Division and have not been relegated since. Twenty-one years after winning the Third Division South, <a href="Brentford%20F.C.">Brentford</a> are relegated to the Third Division South for the first time and do not return to the second tier until 1992. In addition to the success of Midlands teams in the top division, <a href="Port%20Vale%20F.C.">Port Vale</a> won Third Division North by 11 points, going unbeaten at home and conceding a record low of 21 goals. They also became the first Third Division side since the war to reach the semi-final of the FA Cup, losing to West Bromwich Albion.
<a href="Sam%20Bartram">Sam Bartram</a> of <a href="Charlton%20Athletic">Charlton Athletic</a> set a League record on 6 March 1954 becoming the first player with 500 League appearances.
FA Cup.
<a href="West%20Bromwich%20Albion%20F.C.">West Bromwich Albion</a> defeated <a href="Preston%20North%20End%20F.C.">Preston North End</a> 3–2 in the <a href="1954%20FA%20Cup%20Final">1954 FA Cup Final</a> to lift the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> for the fourth time.
